column4: Hello, I was wondering how I could safely mount my ntsf-3 drive?
see here: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/AutomaticallyMountPartitions
thats for the reply, I'll read into it.
would you happen to have a more up to date link. That diskmounter script doesn't exist anymore.
ow sorry... I know the link has (had?) a good explanation as how to use /etc/fstab
to mount a disk, you'll need at least an existing mountpoint (the directory where to attach the disk). Then you'll need to know the drive/partition name
not apposed to trying that just figured that diskmounter would be a safer option, so was just double checking.
well, using fstab file will mount the partition at every boot.
use "sudo fdisk -l" to list all your drives/partitions, then add a line to /etc/fstab file
okay thanks.
would this be correct: /dev/sda /media/hda ntfs ro,auto,user,fmask=0111,dmask=000 0 0
that seems fine indeed. Change "ntfs" in 3rd field to ntfs-3g (necessary for write access)
didn't end up working... is there a log where I can find out why?
what part did not work? The actual mount, or permission problems?
one second I'm looking through the mount -a
I got it to work. The problem was that it needed to be /dev/sda1 rather then /dev/sda
Thanks for the help. <:
ah, ok!
For write access, you also might want to use "ntfs-3g" as filesystem type
it is ntfs-3g
ok sorry, missed that part
the output states that it is mounted 'ro', which is readonly
